[[File:Tyashi.jpg|thumb|right|250px|''Chashi'' in the [[Kushiro Shitsugen National Park|Kushiro wetlands]]]] {{nihongo|'''''Chashi'''''|チャシ also 砦}} is the [[Japanese language|Japanese]] term for the hilltop fortifications of the [[Ainu (people)|Ainu]]. The word is of [[Ainu language|Ainu]] origin, from ''casi'', which means [[palisade]] or palisaded compound; a rival theory relates the term to ''cas''.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=D5iOcHB3h5AC&pg=PA123#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=The Conquest of Ainu Lands: Ecology and Culture in Japanese Expansion, 1590-1800 |author=Walker, Brett L |publisher=[[University of California Press]] |year=2001 |isbn=0-520-22736-0 |pages=36–8, 58–67, 93–4, 123–6}}{{cite web |url=http://www.aisf.or.jp/~jaanus/deta/c/chashi.htm |title=Chashi |publisher=[[Japanese Architecture and Art Net Users System]] |accessdate=21 June 2012}} Over 520 ''chashi'' have been identified in [[Hokkaidō]], mostly in the eastern regions of the island; others are known from southern [[Sakhalin]] and the [[Kurils]]; similar phenomena such as the ''ostrogu'' of [[Kamchatka]] and the ''gorodische'' of northeast Asia may have developed independently.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eTFMPO5NdKgC&pg=PA216#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Ruins of Identity: Ethnogenesis in the Japanese Islands |author=Hudson, Mark |publisher=[[University of Hawaii Press]] |year=2000 |isbn=978-0-824-82156-2 |pages=216–7}}{{cite web |url=http://kaken.nii.ac.jp/en/p/12610426/2003/6/en |title=Establishment process of Chashi and Fortified Settlement Sites in Northeast Asia and their environmental change |author=Ushiro Hiroshi |publisher=[[National Institute of Informatics]] |accessdate=24 June 2012}} A few, including the Tōya ''casi'' of present-day [[Kushiro, Hokkaidō|Kushiro]], date to the [[Muromachi period]]; the remainder date largely to the early seventeenth century. As such their construction may be related to increased competition for resources as a result of "intensification of trade" with the Japanese. ==Form== The early Dutch explorer [[Maarten Gerritsz Vries]] described the ''chashi'' he encountered in eastern Hokkaidō in 1643:
These forts were made as follows: on the mountain on which they were placed was a small road steep to climb, and round on the four sides palisades were placed of the height … of 1½ man's length; within this stood two or three houses. There were large fir doors in the palisades with strong clamps; when they were closed, two stout bars were passed through the clamps and thus fastened to them. At the two corners of these … palisades, a high scaffolding is made of fir planks, for a lookout.
==Competition for resources== [[File:Nemurohanto chashiatogun onnemotochashi.jpg|thumb|right|250px|''Chashi'' on the [[Nemuro Peninsula]] ([[Monuments of Japan|Historic Site]])]] In 1604 [[Tokugawa Ieyasu]] granted exclusive trading rights with the Ainu to the [[Matsumae clan]]; lacking an agricultural base, the domain was dependent on trade; the Ainu in turn became increasingly dependent upon Japanese commodities and prestige goods.{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=UUgNGEkU4DoC&pg=PA27#v=onepage&q&f=false |title=Capitalism from Within: Economy, Society, and the State in a Japanese Fishery |author=Howell, David L |publisher=[[University of California Press]] |year=1995 |isbn=978-0-520-08629-6 |pages=27–35}} Excavated ''chashi'' have revealed Japanese [[Urushi|lacquerware]], [[Japanese ceramics|ceramics]], ironware, and [[Japanese sword|swords]], as well as beads perhaps from Sakhalin; consumables included rice, [[sake]], and tobacco. In return the Ainu traded products derived from bird, beast, and fish; plants and medicines; and goods imported via Sakhalin. However, "the market culture of the trading post … destroy[ed] the ecological balance … [through] overhunting and overfishing". By the end of the following century, the depletion of natural stocks resulted in famine. Furthermore, "competition over animals and fisheries was at the heart of most Ainu conflicts". ==Shakushain's Revolt== The {{nihongo|''Ezo hōki''|蝦夷蜂起|[[Ezo]] Uprising}} and {{nihongo|''Tsugaru ittōshi''|[[:ja:津軽一統志|津軽一統志]]|Tsugaru Unification Record}} recount the internecine conflict of 1668/9, which culminated in massacres of the Japanese, military intervention, and subjugation, in what is known as [[Shakushain's Revolt]]. According to the ''Ezo hōki'', regional influence among the Ainu was based on "good land", "many utensils", [[charismatic authority]], and physical strength. In 1668, disputes over deer, [[Iomante|bear cubs]], and a live crane lead to the Hae elder Chikunashi and his mother burning down the [[Shizunai River|Shibuchari]] ''casi'' and killing the escapees. In response Shakushain sent the [[Urakawa District, Hokkaidō|Urakawa]] Ainu to attack the Atsubetsu ''casi''; driven off by musket fire they returned in force and captured it, after many of its defenders had left in search of food. The conflict escalated the following year into fighting with the Japanese; after his final surrender, Shukushain was killed and the Shibuchari ''casi'' again burned to the ground. ==Known ''chashi''== [[File:Katsuragaoka Chashi.jpg|thumb|right|250px|Katsuragaoka ''chashi'' ([[Monuments of Japan|Historic Site]])]] Among the approximately five hundred and thirty ''chashi'' identified by archaeologists, the sites of eight have been [[Cultural Properties of Japan|designated]] national [[Monuments of Japan|Historic Sites]]: the Otafunbe ''chashi'';{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=401&item_id=61 |title=オタフンベチャシ跡 |trans_title=Otafunbe Chashi Site |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=21 June 2012}} Shibechari River ''chashi'' and Appetsu ''chashi'';{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=401&item_id=3204 |title=シベチャリ川流域チャシ跡群及びアッペツチャシ跡 |trans_title=Shibechari River Chashi Site - Appetsu Chashi Site |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=21 June 2012}} Moshiriya ''chashi'';{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=401&item_id=18 |title=モシリヤ砦跡 |trans_title=Moshiriya Chashi Site |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=21 June 2012}} Yukuepira ''chashi'';{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=401&item_id=18 |title=ユクエピラチャシ跡 |trans_title=Yukuepira Chashi Site |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=21 June 2012}} Katsuragaoka ''chashi'';{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=401&item_id=20 |title=桂ヶ岡砦跡 |trans_title=Katsuragaoka Chashi Site |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=21 June 2012}} [[Nemuro Peninsula]] ''chashi'';{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=401&item_id=66 |title=根室半島チャシ跡群 |trans_title=Nemuro Peninsula Chashi Site |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=21 June 2012}} and Tsurugataicharanke ''chashi''.{{cite web |url=http://kunishitei.bunka.go.jp/bsys/maindetails.asp?register_id=401&item_id=19 |title=鶴ヶ岱チャランケ砦跡 |trans_title=Tsurugataicharanke Chashi Site |language=Japanese |publisher=[[Agency for Cultural Affairs]] |accessdate=21 June 2012}} Others known include the Arashiyama ''casi'', Harutoru ''casi'', Onibishi's ''casi'', Sarushina ''casi'', Sashirui ''casi'', Setanai ''casi'', and Uraike ''casi''. Although there are nineteen ''chashi'' on the [[Shiretoko Peninsula]], it is inscribed as a Natural rather than a mixed [[World Heritage Site#Selection criteria|Natural and Cultural]] UNESCO World Heritage Site.{{cite web |url=http://www.hucc.hokudai.ac.jp/~e20623/siberia/project/kaigi/dublin.pdf |title=World Heritage and Indigenous archaeology in Hokkaido Island |author=Kato Hirofumi |publisher=[[Hokkaido University]] |accessdate=24 June 2012}}{{cite web |url=http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1193/ |title=Shiretoko |publisher=[[UNESCO]] |accessdate=24 June 2012}} ==Functions== In addition to providing for defence against rival Ainu, ''chashi'' functioned as centres for gatherings and rituals.{{cite web |url=http://kaken.nii.ac.jp/ja/p/16520472/2007/6/en |title=Systematic structure of protective settlements and Chashi (Fortes Ainu) found in the northern areas, and ethnic encounters |author=Ushiro Hiroshi |publisher=[[National Institute of Informatics]] |accessdate=24 June 2012}} They also served as "visible symbols of chiefdom power". According to narrative [[uepeker]] or folktales, [[Akkeshi District, Hokkaidō|Akkeshi]] and [[Nemuro Subprefecture|Nemuro]] Ainu attacked the Uraike ''casi'' in the hope of "fine treasure"; other ''chashi'' were attacked by hungry Ainu looking for venison and dried salmon. ==See also== * [[Japanese castle]] * [[Gusuku]] * [[List of Historic Sites of Japan (Hokkaidō)]] ==References== {{reflist}} {{Fortifications}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:Ainu]] [[Category:History of Hokkaido]] [[Category:Castles in Japan]] [[Category:Hill forts]]
